review.title: Discovery of Web Usage Profiles Using Various Clustering Techniques
review.abstract: The explosive growth of World Wide Web (WWW) has necessitated the development of Web personalization systems in order to understand the user preferences to dynamically serve customized content to individual users. To reveal information about user preferences from Web usage data, Web Usage Mining (WUM) techniques are extensively being applied to the Web log data. Clustering techniques are widely used in WUM to capture similar interests and trends among users accessing a Web site. Clustering aims to divide a data set into groups or clusters where inter-cluster similarities are minimized while the intra cluster similarities are maximized. This paper reviews four of the popularly used clustering techniques: k-Means, k-Medoids, Leader and DBSCAN. These techniques are implemented and tested against the Web user navigational data. Performance and validity results of each technique are presented and compared.
histories: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1507.03340

sections.heading: B. K-Medoids Clustering Algorthm:
sections.text: An attempt is made to minimize the squared error, which is the distance between the data points within a cluster and a point designated as the center of that cluster. In contrast to the methods of the k-mean algorithm, the k-medoid algorithm is minimal, i.e. it is a central data point in the cluster [20], [22]. A medoid is a data point of a cluster whose average dissimilarity to all other data points in the cluster is minimal, i.e. it is the most centrally located data point in the cluster [20], [22].Given a set of m data points mixX i 1 |, where each data point is an n-dimensional vector, mdoid tries to partition the algorithms that partition the m data points into k clusters.

sections.heading: C. Leader Clustering Algorthm:
sections.text: The cluster algorithm for managers [23], [24] is based on a pre-defined deviation threshold. First, a random data point is selected from the input data set as the leader. Afterwards, the distance of each second data point to the selected leader is calculated. If the distance of a data point is smaller than the deviation threshold, this data point falls into the cluster with the initial leader. Otherwise, the data point is identified as the new leader. Calculation of the leader will continue until all data points are taken into account. It should be noted that the result of cluster formation depends on the selected distance threshold. The number of leaders is inversely proportional to the selected threshold. In a set of m data points mixX i 1 |, at which each data point is an n-dimensional vector. sections.heading: A. Preprocessing the Web Log Data:
sections.text: After cleaning, the output file contained 12744 entries. The total number of identified unique users is 16 and the number of discovered user sessions 206. Table II shows the results of cleaning and user identification as well as the identification steps of the user sessions of pre-processing. Further details of our pre-processing approaches can be found in our previous paper [26].

sections.heading: RESULTS OF CLEANING AND USER IDENTIFICATION
sections.text: Figure 4 shows the result of identifying user sessions. It shows the percentage of user sessions accessing the specified number of URLs.

sections.heading: B. Clustering of User Navigational Sessions:
sections.text: Once the user sessions are detected, user session data is submitted to the four different cluster algorithms to find session pairs that represent similar URLs. These algorithms are i) k-Means ii) k-Medoids iii) Leader and iv) DBSCAN. Since the above cluster algorithms result in different clusters, it is important to perform an evaluation of the results to assess their quality. We evaluated our results based on DB index and C index, which are two quality measures to evaluate the quality of the clusters detected. This validity measures one described below: Davies-Bouldin Validity Index: This index attempts to determine the average distance between each cluster and the one that is most similar to it. It is defined as: (16), max 11, 1 ki jijiijkj ccdiscdiscdiamcdiamk DBJuly Issue page 23 of this total ISS205C algorithm is the optimum value of the tztztztztzdiamk.

sections.heading: K-MEANS CLUSTERING RESULTS
sections.text: One of the problems associated with the k-Means algorithm is that it can create empty clusters, depending on the initial centering chosen. Diagram in Fig. 6 Describes the number of empty clusters created for different values by k. M.K.Pakhira [29], has proposed a modified k-Medoids algorithm to avoid the empty clusters.2) k-Medoids algorithm: We performed the multiple runs of the k-Medoids algorithm by selecting the input parameter k (number of clusters) in the range of k = 2,..., 67. (The value 67 for the number of clusters corresponds to a third of the total number of user sessions detected.) For each of these runs, we calculated the value of the cluster error function (J) using (7), which represents the sum of the square error.

sections.heading: K-MEDOIDS CLUSTERING RESULTS
sections.text: We compared the k-Means and k-Medoids algorithms on the basis of cluster errors (J as defined in Equations (2) and (7)), cluster validity using the C-Index and execution time. July issue page 24 of 69 ISSN 2229 5208Our results (Fig. 7) show that the k-Means algorithm minimizes cluster error (J) slightly better than the kMedoids algorithm. C index values in Chart Fig. 8 show that the clusters of the k-Means algorithm have a better validity index than the k-Medoids algorithm. On the other hand, the execution times of the k-Medoids algorithms are faster than those of the k-Means algorithm, as shown in Fig.9.3.) Leader algorithm: We performed the multiple runs of the Leader algorithm by calculating the input parameter (dissimilarity thickness index) for each of 0.5 steps of the cluster index, which we also chose from 0.5.

sections.heading: I. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We have given a detailed overview of these techniques. We have also described the mathematical model and algorithm details related to implementing these cluster algorithms in order to discover the user session clusters. From the results presented in the previous section, we conclude the following points. K-mean clustering produces a fairly higher accuracy and lower cluster errors compared to the cluster algorithms. K-mean algorithm can lead to the formation of an empty cluster, whereas it is not the case with k-medoids algorithm. Our result shows that k-medoids algorithm provides a relatively better time performance than that of the kmeans algorithm. The reason for this is that we use a large dataset.

referenceMentions.context: INTRODUCTION Web Usage Mining [1] is described as the automatic discovery and analysis of patterns in web logs and associated data collected as a result of user interactions with Web resources on one or more Web sites.

Web usage mining has been used in a variety of applications such as i) Web Personalization systems [2], ii) Adaptive Web Sites [3][4], iii) Business Intelligence [5], iv) System Improvement to understand the web traffic behaviour which can be utilized to decide strategies for web caching [6], load balancing and data distribution [7], iv) Fraud detection: detection of unusual accesses to the secured data [8], etc.

metadata.abstractText: The explosive growth of World Wide Web (WWW) has necessitated the development of Web personalization systems in order to understand the user preferences to dynamically serve customized content to individual users. To reveal information about user preferences from Web usage data, Web Usage Mining (WUM) techniques are extensively being applied to the Web log data. Clustering techniques are widely used in WUM to capture similar interests and trends among users accessing a Web site. Clustering aims to divide a data set into groups or clusters where inter-cluster similarities are minimized while the intra cluster similarities are maximized. This paper reviews four of the popularly used clustering techniques: k-Means, k-Medoids, Leader and DBSCAN. These techniques are implemented and tested against the Web user navigational data. Performance and validity results of each technique are presented and compared. (Abstract) Keywords-component; web usage mining; k-means clustering; kmedoids clustering; leader clustering; DBSCAN
